titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Copies of letters to and from Col. William Legge
Legge (Col. William), Copies of letters to and from
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 30, 2019 at 03:02

did.unittitle: Copies of letters to and from Col. William Legge, transcribed from the originals in the possession of William Fourth Earl of Dartmouth, during the years 1816 and 1817, by William, 2nd Lord Bagot.

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Autograph MS. Contains copies of 373 letters, illustrated with prints and drawings.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased by James Marshall Osborn from Maggs in 1958. Bequest of James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn, 1976.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copies of letters to and from Col. William Legge, transcribed from the originals in the possession of William Fourth Earl of Dartmouth, during the years 1816 and 1817, by William, 2nd Lord Bagot is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Copies of letters to and from Col. William Legge, transcribed from the originals in the possession of William Fourth Earl of Dartmouth, during the years 1816 and 1817, by William, 2nd Lord Bagot. James Marshall and Marie-Louise Osborn Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was produced from a previously existing list or card set. All pertinent bibliographical information has been retained; the volume may contain additional unlisted material.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Portion available on microfilm from Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The following finding aid is a complete inventory of the contents of Osborn fb190. This list was reformatted from previously existing cataloging.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
Golt
1 p.
Regrets not being able to see him
this time but hopes to after Legge
finishes at Hull.
L.1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Yorke]
2 p.
Written at Hull; proposes that
Newport rendezvous with the King at
Nortallerton and then march towards
Hull; Legge is to prepare to march.
L.2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
2 p.
Reports a skirmish with the Scots;
orders Legge to prepare the defense
of Hull and to await his arrival.
L.3.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Skipton Castle]
2 p.
Asks if Henry Rich, 1st earl of
Holland will keep the army at York
until the next week.
L.4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[London]
4 p.
Gives news of the Long Parliament
on funding for the army, debates of
the Triennial Act, and the
arraignment of Thomas Wentworth, 1st
earl of Strafford.
L.5.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[London]
2 p.
Describes the problems over the
arraignment of Lord Strafford in
Parliament and other news from
London.
L.6.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[London]
2 p.
Gives news of the Long Parliament
and the Commons' determination
against Strafford.
L.7.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
2 p.
Relates the situation in the north
and begs him to ask Henry Rich, 1st
earl of Holland for more money for
the army.
L.7.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Tyon]
1 p.
That he has ordered the treasurer,
Sir Jacob Astley, 1st baron
(1579-1652), to pay Legge and
promises not to let his army's pay
fall behind the rest of the troops'
again.
L.8.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[London]
4 p.
Relates the Long Parliament's
discovery of the first Army Plot and
growing opposition to the King.
L.10.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[London]
4 p.
Commons now intends to raise money in
order to disband some of the troops.
L.11-12.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Stockhill]
1 p.
That he is sorry to hear of Legge's
accident (unspecified).
L.13.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
3 p.
Describes his feelings towards
serving Lord Holland and complains of
being misunderstood by Parliament.
L.15.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Huntington]
1 p.
Requests the four horses provided by
the County of Huntington be returned.
Signed also by Thomas Cotton, 2nd
bart. (1594-1662) and Henry Cromwell
(1628-1674).
L.16.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Steeton]
1 p.
Orders that a Mr West bring the
bills of his quarter to Fairfax and
that Legge is to see they are paid.
L.17.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Eamesby]
1 p.
Requests Legge's assistance that the
cart horses Lindsey raised from
Lincolnshire, when discharged, be
sent to Sir William Pelham.
L.18.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Studley?]
4 p.
Warns Legge of a Mr Donnell who is
rumored to be about to petition
Parliament to review for fraud
Legge's powder disbursements and
accounts at the Exchequer.
L.19.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[London]
3 p.
That Newport has decided to lodge in
the tower and offer his house to the
Queen of Bohemia (Elizabeth of
England, queen consort of
Frederick I).
L.20.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Oxford]
2 p.
That he has been ill and would
provide some intelligence if he
thought that Prince Rupert "would
either receive it better, or make
better use of it."
L.21a

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Oxford]
3 p.
Orders Legge to quarter Rupert's
troops in Berkshire and hold monthly
councils to review petitions and
complaints.
L.21b

did.unittitle: CHARLES I, KING OF GREAT BRITAIN, 1600-1649

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
2 p.
Requests him to relieve Newark-on-
Trent which is being besieged by
Lords Willoughby and Grey, Sir John
Gell, and Sir John Meldrum.
L.22.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1 p.
That Rupert would accept the
Mastership of the Horse if it did
not look like he had caused the ruin
of James Hamilton, 3rd marquis of
Hamilton (1606-1649).
L.23.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Hereford]
2 p.
Sir Edward Herbert recommends that
Rupert accept the Mastership of the
Horse if the King offers it, and
reviews a recent defeat of Edward
Massey.
L.24.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1 p.
Accept the Mastership, gives his
marching plans for the King, and
remembers his services to Lord
Buckingham and James Stuart, 1st
duke of Richmond (1612-1655).
L.25.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Bristol]
2 p.
Warns that there is a party for
peace forming that finds Rupert the
major obstacle, and that Charles I
has promised to punish them.
L.26.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Ludlow]
2 p.
Partially in cipher; warns that
Wales will revolt since Rupert is
preoccupied elsewhere and that their
situation is desperate.
L.27.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Ludlow]
2 p.
Rupert hopes to join Prince Maurice;
Legge is to let him know when the
train will be ready to march.
L.28.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Ludlow]
2 p.
That he hears Bristol is very poorly
guarded and not a fit place for
Prince Charles and that Ralph
Hopton, 1st baron, desires its
absolute command.
L.29.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Loughborough]
3 p.
Requests that Legge withstand
Fairfax's siege of Oxford for one
month to six weeks more.
L.30.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Hereford]
2 p.
That he cannot visit Legge at Oxford
but asks whether Prince Charles has
the King's permission to issue orders
to General George Goring, baron
(1608-1657).
L.31.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Burford]
1 p.
Legge is to become Commander in
Chief for the defense of Oxford.
L.32.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Leicester]
Desired that Legge hold out at
Oxford for a month to six weeks so
that Bristol can take advantage of a
victory at Leicester.
L.33.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Daventree]
2 p.
An effort to separate the soldiers,
and their influence, from the King
has failed.
L.34.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Bewdley]
2 p.
Asks the reaction to Rupert's defeat
at Naseby and warns that George
Digby, 2nd earl of Bristol, is
prejudicing the King against Rupert.
L.35.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Hereford]
3 p.
Defends his criticisms of Prince
Rupert and gives analysis of the
Battle of Naseby.
L.36.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Bristol]
2 p.
That the army has been forced back
and that the King "intends for
Scotland."
L.37.

did.unittitle: CHARLES I, KING OF GREAT BRITAIN, 1600-1649

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Broomyard]
2 p.
Requests that their design for Ely
and Cambridge be postponed a week.
L.38.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
2 p.
Regrets that he did not meet Legge
because he was busy preparing to
disband the troops and send Charles
to Scotland.
L.39.

did.unittitle: CHARLES I, KING OF GREAT BRITAIN, 1600-1649

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Newcastle]
1 p.
Regrets that he has not written,
having heard nothing from the south.
L.40.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1 p.
That Legge has complete discretion in
the government of the North although
peace with the Scots is not expected
to last long.
L.41.

did.unittitle: CHARLES I, KING OF GREAT BRITAIN, 1600-1649

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Hampton Court]
1 p.
Letter of introduction for William
Legge who is to relate an
unidentified message to James Stuart,
1st duke of Richmond.
L.42.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Castle Lyons]
1 p.
Enclosed Legge's instructions and
warned him not to be upset if Ormonde
is not an admirer of Prince Rupert.
L.43.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Arundel Castle]
4 p.
Describes his own and the
imprisonment of King Charles;
discusses the motives of the Scots.
L.44.

did.unittitle: CHARLES I, KING OF GREAT BRITAIN, 1600-1649

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
5 p.
Orders Legge to go to Ireland and
inform Prince Rupert, Lord Ormonde,
and other Catholic supporters, that
the King intends to support the
Peace and that he wishes to come to
Ireland but is without funds.
L.45a.

did.unittitle: DERBY, CHARLOTTE STANLEY, COUNTESS OF, D.1644

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Knowsley]
3 p.
Requests Legge to ask the King to
assist her fatherless family, perhaps
with a title.
L.46a.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[The Hague]
2 p.
Relates his sea voyages and that he
is on his way to Vienna.
L.46b.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[The Hague]
3 p.
That his departure for Cleve to meet
the Prince of Orange has been delayed
by creditors, and that his mother is
not pleased with Lord William Craven
(1606-1697).
L.47.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Cleve]
3 p.
Suggests a Dutch engineer, De Rues,
be used on the fortification of
Portsmouth.
L.48.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[1661 Nov 2 and 12]
[Frankfurt and Cassell]
3 p.
Relates his journey on the way to
Rotterdam and requests that the Duke
of York provide him with a frigate.
L.58.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Dublin]
4 p.
Discusses the problem of financing
the army in Ireland.
L.60.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Dublin]
2 p.
Relates John Berkeley, 1st baron
Berkeley's desire to resign the
Lord-presidency of Connaught and
Ormonde's opposition to that office.
L.61.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[1665 Sep 2 and Oct 25]
[Kilkenny and Dublin]
3 p.
Reviews the laws inhibiting the
cattle and plantation trade and the
lack of money for the army in
Ireland.
L.62-63.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Dublin]
1 p.
Hopes to visit him in England soon.
L.64.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[1665 Nov 18 to 1666 May 30]
[Dublin]
6 p.
Gives domestic news and Ormonde's
belief that Ireland must have free
trade or constant subsidies from
England.
L.65-68.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Dublin]
2 p.
Complains that Charles Stuart, 5th
duke of Richmond, has not paid her
portion to her and discusses other
money matters.
L.69.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Orchard Windame]
2 p.
That he succeeded in waiting on the
lady at her own house, "which was as
much, I could expect at my Firste
approche."
L.70.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Welbeck]
2 p.
Requests Legge to congratulate
Charles II on the defeat of a Dutch
fleet.
L.71.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Morepark]
2 p.
She is humiliated for having no money
to pay her servants or creditors.
L.72.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Dublin]
2 p.
That he feels the treaty between his
son John and Warre's daughter is
fair and hopes only that his son's
financial condition will improve.
L.73.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[1666 Aug 30 and Sep 12]
[Kilkenny and Clonmell]
4 p.
Comments on the naval struggle with
the French and Dutch; on his son
John's difficulties with a Mrs
Mallet; suggests that Legge might
wish to marry his daughter to the
son of Piers Butler, 5th baron
Dunboyne (d.1690).
L.74-75.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Dublin]
2 p.
That he has sent Arthur Annesley,
3rd earl of Anglesey to bargain with
Lord Richmond regarding his wife's
portion.
L.76.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[(1666) Oct 3 & 7, Kilkenny]
3 p.
Enclosed a letter for Legge's daughter
and apparently some money so that he
could "conclude or decline the Mache,
proposed for hir"; also discusses her
son John's pursuit of a Lady.
L.77-78.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Kilkenny]
2 p.
Urges speed in the deliberation with
Sir John Warre over his son John and
wishes no advantage to Francis
Hawley, baron Hawley (1608?-1684).
L.79.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Kilkenny]
2 p.
Regarding a proposed match between
his son John and Warre's daughter-
in-law.
L.80.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Dublin]
2 p.
That she has not been well and that
she is pleased Lady Ormonde approves
of her.
L.81.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Dublin]
1 p.
Thanks him for managing the affairs
of her son John.
L.82.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Dublin]
2 p.
Asks that Legge have her mother
(Mary Villiers Herbert Stuart Howard,
(1622-1685) write her.
L.83.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Hestercoome]
2 p.
That a young lady refuses to marry
the Duke of Ormonde's son (John
Butler, 1st earl of Gowran) despite
his efforts.
L.84.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[London]
2 p.
That the lady declined to marry Lord
Ormonde's son of her own accord.
L.85.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[London]
2 p.
Regrets that the lady has declined
the match.
L.86.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[1666 Nov 22 to Nov 29]
[Chapelizard]
4 p.
That her son John is pursuing his
mistress in London; invites Legge to
visit London.
L.87-89.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Kilkenny and Dublin]
3 p.
That his son John has gone to London
to visit his lady and requests Legge
counsel him.
L.90-91.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[1666 Dec 18 & 1667 Jan 27]
[Dublin]
2 p.
Encloses letters for her son John
and informs Legge that she is trying
to find a match for his daughter.
L.92-93.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Dublin]
2 p.
That she is healthy and happy and
requests Legge to speak with Charles
Stuart Richmond, 5th duke of
Richmond, regarding what he owes her.
L.94.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1 p.
Thanks Legge for his efforts on
behalf of her son.
L.95.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Dublin]
2 p.
Hopes that Lord Richmond will
finally pay her what he owes and
that her mother, Mary (Villiers)
Herbert Stuart Howard, will write.
L.96.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
2 p.
Regrets that Legge declined the
marriage for his daughter that she
had tried to arrange.
L.97.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Dublin]
1 p.
Thanks him for his efforts on behalf
of his son and expresses satisfaction
with his daughter-in-law.
L.98.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Lichfield]
2 p.
Relates his affections for his
future wife (Barbara [Archibold]
Legge, Dartmouth).
L.99.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Alicant Road]
3 p.
On the problems of administering his
fleet.
L.100.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[1672 Dec 17 & 24]
[Whitehall]
3 p.
Requests that he investigate reports
of a felon being sheltered in
Portsmouth and later that the felon
has been captured.
L.1-2.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 2 p. That he is having problems supplying George Villiers, 2nd duke of Buckingham's companies. L.3.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Guernsey]
2 p.
Offers his services, suggesting that
he purchase wine for Dartmouth.
L.4.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
2 p.
On Dartmouth's moving into a former
residence of Plymouth's.
L.5.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Jamaica]
3 p.
Describes his arrival in Jamaica
and his attempts to impose law.
L.6.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
2 p.
Encloses a proxy vote signed for
King Charles II.
L.7-8.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Derby House]
2 p.
The Lords of the Admiralty have
ordered the principal officers of
the navy to provide warrants for 60
men for the security of Plymouth
Harbor.
L.9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[1677 May 30 and Jun 19]
[Tower of London]
3 p.
Requests Charles II be asked to
release him.
L.10-11.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Edlington]
3 p.
Begs forgiveness for his conduct in
London and complains of the King's
refusal to help his brother.
L.12.

did.unittitle: WHARTON, ANNE (KERR) POPHAM WHARTON, COUNTESS OF, D.1692

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
1 p.
Discusses her petition to the King
for her imprisoned son.
L.13.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Tower of London]
5 p.
Recounts his attempts to have the
King free him from the Tower.
L.14-17.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Tower of London]
1 p.
Lord Wharton requests his petition
for freedom from the Tower that he
presented after James Cecil, 3rd
earl of Salisbury's petition to the
King.
L.18.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[1667 Jul 22 & 24]
[Tower of London]
3 p.
On his need to be released from the
Tower.
L.19-20.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Tower of London]
2 p.
Requests that he inform George
Legge, 1st baron Dartmouth, that
Lady Wharton (Anne Kerr Popham
Wharton) has asked the Duke of York
to petition the King on his behalf.
L.21.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Tower of London]
1 p.
Contains an excerpt of his petition.
L.22.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Goate Tavern]
2 p.
Offers to carry papers to his father.
L.23.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Whitehall]
1 p.
That he read his request for Sir
John Kempthorne to the King but that
the request for Mr. Pepys will
probably not be granted.
L.24.

did.unittitle: JAMES II, KING OF GREAT BRITAIN, 1633-1701

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[1679 Mar 28 to Oct 8]
[Brussels]
26 p.
Describes the events of his temporary
exile from England; gives his
personal view on people, politics,
and religion; advice for Charles II.
Mentioned are Sir John Werden, bart.
(1640-1716); Arthur Capel, earl of
Essex (1631-1683); Henry Hyde, 2nd
earl of Clarendon (1638-1709); George
Savile, 1st marquis of Halifax
(1633-1695); James Scott, duke of
Monmouth (1649-1685); Arthur
Annesley, earl of Anglesey
(1614-1686); Anthony Ashley Cooper,
1st earl of Shaftesbury (1621-1683);
Thomas Osborne, 1st duke of Leeds
(1631-1712); Horatio Townshend 1st
viscount Townshend (1630?-1687).
L.25-41.

did.unittitle: JAMES II, KING OF GREAT BRITAIN, 1633-1701

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[1679 Nov 13 to 1680 Feb 10]
[Edinburgh]
41 p.
Describes his temporary exile to
Scotland and his petitions to be
recalled to London. Gives opinions
on his own religion, Charles II's
monarchy, and contemporary politics.
Mentioned are Arthur Capel, earl of
Essex (1631-1683); James Scott, duke
of Monmouth (1649-1685); Anthony
Ashley Cooper, 1st earl of
Shaftesbury (1621-1683); John
Churchill, 1st duke of Marlborough
(1650-1722); William Howard, 1st
viscount Stafford (1614-1680);
Archibald Campbell, 9th earl of
Argyll (d.1685).
L.42-70.

did.unittitle: [Letter to Robert Spencer, 2nd earl of Sunderland (1640-1702)]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Plymouth]
2 p.
Requests additional men for his
garrison at Plymouth and complains
of deserters.
L.71.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[Windsor]
1 p.
Reports the King will supply
additional men to Plymouth and wishes
to see Major (Sir Martin) Beckman.
L.72.

did.unittitle: JAMES II, KING OF GREAT BRITAIN, 1633-1701

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p:
[1680, Nov 2 to Dec 14]
[Edinburgh]
9 p.
Comments on his determination to
remain a Catholic and urges the King
to stand firm against Lord
Shaftesbury and his party.
L.73-75.

did.unittitle: Papers written by Lord Dartmouth from the Tower of London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Papers written by Lord Dartmouth during his confinement in the Tower of London, ending with his death on October 25, 1691. The 26 pages include the warrant for his arrest, "you are to apprehend [Dartmouth] and seize for High Treason" and the events that follow. Dartmouth professes his innocence, but promises to arrive in London the next morning, keeping the arrest a secret from his family by pretending to have urgent business in London "as indeed it was." Upon arrival, he is summoned by Lord Nottingham and others to stand trial. A series of questions, along with Dartmouth's pleas of loyalty to England, follow. "My Lords I am a plaine man, and I desire to answer plainly; I positively protest I have received nothing from [King James] directly or indirectly" (p.725).

After the trial, Dartmouth is put in custody of the Sergeant at Arms, although he protests that "I had rather stay, tho I were sure to dye in England, than go to live in France" (p.733). In the end, Dartmouth fails to prove his innocence, and is sent to the Tower (p.739). His last letter, written to Lord Sydney [Henry Sidney, earl of Romney (1641-1704)] states that "to find myself thus stigmatized as a Traytor to my Country, and that in the behalfe of France, is the greiviousest burthen can possibly be lay'd upon me."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes additional letters and papers relating to Lord Dartmouth's expedition to Tangiers, undated letters, and miscellaneous papers:

did.unittitle: "The way to give the most generall satisfaction to all Inhabitants", p.III.
2 letters from Lord Rochester to Lord Dartmouth, n.y. Aug. 1, p.VII.
"The Lord Dartmouth's speech to the Military Officers of the Garrison of Tanger, October the 4th, 1683", p.IX.
2 letters from Samuel Pepys concerning Tangiers and severe flooding in Spain, p.XII.
Letter from Dartmouth to Sir L. Tenkins at his return from Tangiers, Plymouth, 1684 Mar 30, p.XVI.
Letter from Mr. Dupaz, Whitehall, 1684 Apr 2, p. XVIII.
Letter from Dr. O. Wynne, Whitehall, 1684 Apr 2, p.XX.
Letter from Sir Henry Sheeres (d.1710), Whitehall, 1684 Apr 5, p.XXII.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains undated letters from Laurence Hyde, 1st earl of Rochester (1641-1711), the Earl of Aylesbury, Lord Mordaunt [Charles, Mordaunt, 3rd earl of Peterborough and 1st earl of Monmouth, (1658-1735)], a translated letter from Ali. Ben. Abdalla reporting the King's presence at the Imperial Court of Mequinez, Sir Henry Sheeres (d.1710), James Fitzjames, duke of Berwick (1670-1734), the Earl of Scarsdale, and 3 letters from Dartmouth to the Duke of York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A paper written on 1679 May 11 by Dartmouth, p.XLII; discusses a debate concerning a proposal to the King that the Duke of York may not enter England without the consent of the King and both houses of Parliament, and other legal matters.

A paper by Dartmouth entitled: "Reasons about the Succession"; "The Succession of the Crowne, cannot be transferred by Act of Parliament, from the Right Heire to any other person, for these Reasons", p.XLVII.
An unendorsed paper concerning "whether itt bee in the interest of England to make such Leagues, which shall certanly engage us in a warre with ffrance" and other related concerns.
